title: Will my terminal master's GPA (3.32) in experimental psychology be a red flag when continuing to experimental psychology PhD programs (bare min to continue MA here is a 3.0 overall)? - Quora

response.answer_text: Steve Roberts wrote: “It really depends on the PhD-granting institution and its requirements. I recommend you contact the specific institutions that you want to attend for the PhD,” but Quora said his answer “needs improvement” and they collapsed it. I second Steve’s suggestion, but, in addition, it also depends on what the top possible GPA is at the school where you got your MA, and what subjects you got Cs (or lower) in. If the top GPA is a 4.0, a 3.32 doesn’t look that bad, but if it’s a 5.0, the, as you point out, your 3.32 is just above the bare minimum. If you got C grades in statistics, that could count heavily against you, but if it was in a foreign language or a humanities course that might not matter all that much. Another variable is how many other students are applying to do a PhD in experimental psychology in the program(s) you are applying to. Experimental psych is much less competitive than other specialties such as clinical, and you might look OK given their applicant pool. Take Steve’s advice and talk to admissions people at the school(s) you want to attend.
It really depends on the PhD-granting institution and its requirements. I recommend you contact the specific institutions that you want to attend for the PhD.
